greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The number of positive integers <= n that are strongly prime to n.
comment: k is strongly prime to n if and only if k is relatively prime to n and k does not divide n - 1.
a(n) = phi(n) - tau(n-1) if n > 0 and a(0) = 0. Here phi(n) = A000010(n) and tau(n) = A000005(n).
It is conjectured (see Scroggs link) that a(n) is also the number of cardboard braids that work with n slots. - _Matthew Scroggs_, Sep 23 2017
a(n) is odd if and only if n is in A002522 but n <> 2. - _Robert Israel_, Jun 20 2018
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Matthew Scroggs, Braiding, pt. 2. Two results and a conjecture
maple: StrongCoprimes := n -> select(k -> igcd(k,n)=1,{$1..n}) minus divisors(n-1):
mathematica: a[0]=0; a[1]=1; a[n_ /; n > 1] := Select[Range[n], CoprimeQ[#, n] && !Divisible[n-1, #] &] // Length; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 66}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jun 26 2013 *)
results.author: _Peter Luschny_, Nov 17 2010
